importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Eurostar expects to start using the first six double-decker trains in 2031, marking a significant milestone in the rollout of the new train fleet.
The announcement of the double-decker train order was made on this date, signaling a pivotal step in Eurostar’s service expansion and infrastructure investment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The train deployment spans from the announcement in 2025 to full operational use by 2031, involving a multi-year certification and deployment process.

keyTakeAways: Eurostar has ordered up to 50 double-decker 'Celestia' trains from Alstom, with 30 already confirmed and an option for 20 more.
The new trains will be 4.33 meters high, just 16 cm taller than current E320 models, and will allow for approximately 1,080 seats when two trains run together.
The first double-decker high-speed trains through the Channel Tunnel represent a historic first for the UK, as the only prior instance of double-deckers on British railways was in 1949.
The expansion includes a 30% increase in trains serving London, with a new investment of €80 million in the Temple Mills depot in London to support the larger trains.
The Temple Mills depot is currently exclusively used by Eurostar and is the only UK depot capable of accommodating continental European high-speed trains.
Eurostar aims to grow passenger numbers from 19.5 million (2024) to 30 million, supported by increased capacity and comfort.
The move comes amid growing competition from firms like Evolyn, Virgin, and a Gemini Trains-Uber partnership, prompting regulatory scrutiny over access to the Temple Mills depot.
The Office of Rail and Road is reviewing proposals from all parties on access to the Temple Mills depot, with a decision expected within weeks.
Railway experts and enthusiasts express skepticism about the feasibility of widespread double-decker adoption due to the age and infrastructure limitations of the UK rail network.
Railway journalist Tony Miles suggests the move may be a strategic response to competition and an opportunity to replace aging stock before retirement.

namedEntities.name: Eurostar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cross-Channel rail operator providing high-speed services between London and Paris, and other European cities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Eurostar is central to the article, as it is the entity announcing and implementing the first double-decker trains through the Channel Tunnel, marking a major shift in its fleet and service offerings.

namedEntities.name: Alstom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global manufacturer of trains and rolling stock, including the provider of Eurostar's new 'Celestia' double-decker trains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Alstom is the key manufacturer behind the new train fleet, playing a critical role in the technological and logistical implementation of the expansion.

namedEntities.name: Temple Mills depot
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A London-based railway depot owned by the London St Pancras Highspeed organisation and currently exclusively used by Eurostar.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Temple Mills is essential for housing and maintaining the new double-decker trains, and its exclusive use by Eurostar raises questions about competition and access for other rail operators.

namedEntities.name: Gwendoline Cazenave
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief executive of Eurostar, who publicly expressed pride in the rollout of double-decker trains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a key spokesperson for the initiative, emphasizing comfort, innovation, and growth in passenger capacity.

namedEntities.name: Tony Miles
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Railway journalist and commentator who analyzed the strategic implications of Eurostar’s double-decker expansion.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His insights offer an external perspective on whether the move is a response to competition or a forward-looking investment.

namedEntities.name: Pete Waterman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Music producer and train enthusiast who provided expert commentary on the feasibility of double-decker trains in the UK.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He highlights technical and historical challenges in integrating double-deckers into Britain’s 200-year-old rail network.

namedEntities.name: Mark Smith
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Founder of Seat61.com, a website focused on international train travel, who praised the comfort benefits of upper deck seats.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His perspective adds value from a passenger experience standpoint, emphasizing the benefits of enhanced seating and views.

namedEntities.name: Evolyn
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Spanish start-up proposing cross-Channel rail services to compete with Eurostar.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents a key competitive threat to Eurostar, raising concerns about market access and depot usage.

namedEntities.name: Virgin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A rail company led by Sir Richard Branson, with ambitions to enter the cross-Channel market.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Virgin is cited as a competitor potentially challenging Eurostar’s dominance in cross-Channel services.

namedEntities.name: Gemini Trains and Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A partnership between a train operator and a technology company aiming to introduce alternative cross-Channel rail services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This joint venture signals growing competition in the sector and adds pressure on Eurostar’s access to key infrastructure like Temple Mills.

namedEntities.name: Office of Rail and Road
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The UK regulatory body overseeing rail infrastructure and service access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is reviewing access to the Temple Mills depot and will decide whether other operators can use it, central to competition and infrastructure fairness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eurostar has announced plans to introduce the first double-decker high-speed trains through the Channel Tunnel, ordering 30 'Celestia' trains from Alstom with an option for 20 more. The trains, expected to begin service in 2031, will increase capacity and comfort, with each train offering about 1,080 seats when operating in tandem. The move comes amid growing competition from rivals such as Evolyn, Virgin, and a Gemini Trains-Uber partnership. Eurostar plans to invest €80 million in the Temple Mills depot in London to support the new fleet, which is currently exclusively used by Eurostar. While the initiative promises greater passenger capacity and comfort, experts question the feasibility of widespread adoption due to the age and infrastructure limitations of the UK rail network. Regulatory scrutiny over access to the Temple Mills depot is underway, with the Office of Rail and Road expected to make a decision within weeks.
title: Eurostar orders first double-decker trains
